lines.text: dig Wagonen
REPRINE
f3B
HYPOLIPIDEMIC EFFECT OF PROPANE-1, 2-DIOL ON
THE MORPHOLOGY OF RAT ERYTHROCYTES
PUsHpa AHLUWaliA AnD M. K. P. AMMA
(Biochemistry Department,Panjab University, Chandigarh, India)
Notice: This material may be
protected by copyright law
. (Received: 19 November, 1984)
(Title 17 U.S. Codo).
ABSTRACT
Fuoctiongl impairment of the erythrocytes could be attributed to the alterations in the membrane
lipids composition leading to morphological changes. Propane-l, 2-diol ingestion to male adult rats at
a dose level of 284 ul per I00 gm. body weight for 30 days has been shown to deplete the membrane
cholesterol and phospholipids. This led to the cbanges in the red ceil morphology as visualized under
Electron microscope..
InTroDuCtIOn
The arcbitecture of the red cell membrane is regulated mainly by the composition
of lipids and proteins, Kirby & Green, (I980). The exposure to a great variety of
amphillic agents in vitro induces the formation of spiculated or spurred cells, Robins &
Miller, (1974) and Vatsala & Singh. (1980). Both depletion and repletion of cholesterol has
an effect on membrane surface and caused a change in the shape of red cells. "Studies
with Propane-1, 2-diol (PG), a widely used solvent in drug, pharmaceutics and food
industry showed that this solvent at a dose level of 284 μl in water per 100 gm. 'body
weight to adult male albino rats for 30 days, caused significant lowering of plasma and
blood lipids, Amma et al., (1978). Tbis observation led us to study the effect of ingestion
of this solvent on the red cell morphology and membrane lipids.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Normal adult male albino rats were divided into two groups of six animals each.
In addition to standard laboratory diet and water ad libtum, control group was given
orally 1 ml of distilled water and test group was given 284 ul of Propane-1, 2-diol (PG)
in water for 30 days." On the 3lst day, fasting blood was taken from optical vein.
The blood was centrifuged, erythrocytes were separated and washed thrice with 0.155 M
by the method of Cilive & Ozand (1972) using Tris-HCi buffer (0.01 M, pH 7.2).
cold saline. An aliquot of the washed cells was used to prepare erythrocyte membranes
Membrane lipids were extracted by the method of Floch (1957). Membrane total lipids
were estimated by the procedures of Zlatkis et al (1953); Fiske and Subba Row (1925)
and Frings (1972) respectively. The other parts of the erythrocytes was treated with
2.5% glutaraldehyde buffered in 0.1 M Cacodylate buffer (pH 7.2) at 4°C for 3 hours
and then was fixed in I% osmium tetroxide buffered with veronal-acetic acid buffer
(pH 7.4), by the method of Glauert (1974). The scanning of erythrocytes was done
[Research Bulletin (Science) of the Panjab University, Vol. 35, Parts II-IV, Pp. I57-I59, December, 1984]
Res. Bull. Panjablriv., Sci
